entry.title: Ignorance =? Bliss
entry.content:
People sure seem to like to talk about themselves being ignorant. But just go and call someone ignorant and see what happens.

I‚Äôve heard it said that being called ignorant is tops for bad things to be called. Now whether that is a true statement remains to be seen. Still it makes me wonder. Is the saying true? Is ignorance bliss?

When people talk about ignorance as a blissful state, they are usually talking about the fact that they are unaware of something. Perhaps it‚Äôs because they‚Äôve been caught doing something that they‚Äôre not supposed to be doing (e.g., breaking the law because they didn‚Äôt know the law). Or perhaps it‚Äôs because it‚Äôs their last resort reasoning for why they aren‚Äôt caught up on the facts (e.g., people not up on things like politics).

But it doesn‚Äôt seem altogether like I have to buy ignorance as an excuse. Do I really care if someone didn‚Äôt know that it was illegal to yield to me at a signal when they‚Äôve just caused an accident? No, frankly ignorance as an excuse is useless. Facts are facts.

So is it bliss? Maybe. But it sure is an extraordinarily weak argument/excuse/cop-out no matter why you‚Äôre saying it.

entry.title: Driving ~ Playing The Stock Market
entry.content:
Lots of people drive. Although perhaps we should rethink the way that we do it, what with the amount of money we‚Äôre sinking into our traveling. While there is much to think about (least of all are my Tips For Saving Gas), you can also find lessons that aren‚Äôt initially obvious. And by you, I mean me.

Driving everyday to work has taught me a few things. One thing that I‚Äôve recently noticed is how it seems to me that I need to just chill when I‚Äôm driving. That is, it does no good to constantly switch lanes in order to try to get ahead. While I may get ahead a little bit, just a single wrong choice, and I‚Äôve lost all that I‚Äôve worked so hard to get.

So it is with stocks as well.

  • Fairly common advice is that you should buy for the long term. The extra stress, work, and volatility are said to just not be worth it. That is, you could do all of that work and still end up at the same place as someone who just set it and left it. And that definitely happens to people when they‚Äôre switching lanes trying to get around all of the other people. It‚Äôs perhaps even more noticeable since a good deal of the road that I drive is 2 lanes.

  • Don‚Äôt be shocked if something abruptly happens to you. If you‚Äôre going someplace and you need to be on time, isn‚Äôt it always better to be early and prepared rather than cutting it as close as possible? That way, if something happens, you‚Äôll have some leeway to recover. And don‚Äôt you dare go putting all over your money into 1 stock. Or even all of your money into stocks!

  • Notice patterns. When driving the same route everyday, I start to get a sense of how things are. That is, some lanes are more apt to progress more quickly because of the traffic flow. And I start to notice how lights are set up so I know whether it‚Äôs worth it to bust my butt to make the light. Alright so maybe that‚Äôs hard to make into some lesson for stocks because the whole deal with the stock market is that people are trying to predict what companies are going to do. And it‚Äôs only partially based on past performance. Still, take that past into account when doing your stock-picking thing.

The comparison doesn‚Äôt hold up completely, of course. While you don‚Äôt have to buy stocks, you do have to pick a lane to drive in. But you know what? I‚Äôm not concerning myself with making a perfect comparison.

entry.title: Relationship Games
entry.content:
An easy way to differentiate between people that are young and old are how they deal with relationships. Even more important than their years (after all age is just a number) is the maturity with which they handle things.

So what do people do? They play games. What are games? They are things like:

  • Girls saying no when they actually mean yes [caption id=‚Äù‚Äù align=‚Äùalignright‚Äù width=‚Äù160‚Äù caption=‚ÄùCourtesy of Flickr user Karla‚Äù][/caption]

  • Guys not wanting to express how they actually feel because it‚Äôs not ‚Äúmanly‚Äù

  • Similarly guys pretending to be completely uninterested

  • Girls playing hard to get (when they actually do want the pursuer to ‚Äúcatch‚Äù them)

  • Both reading into all kinds of actions, lack of actions, subtle tones, sly looks, the way they laugh when you‚Äôre around, and all manner of intricacies that I do not have knowledge of

  • A girl leading a guy (or vice versa) to think that a relationship might happen at some future time

When we play these games, it‚Äôs all smoke and mirrors. And if the goal of relationships is marriage, then how is that helpful in accomplishing that goal? It‚Äôs not.

Guys need to ask the girl out, straight up. (I had my fun being sarcastic about it On Asking A Girl Out by saying what you should not be doing.) But you need to make it crystal clear to her what you want and what you‚Äôre doing. Otherwise you‚Äôre just beating around the bush and wasting everyone‚Äôs time.

Girls need to act purposefully. You want him? Go with it if he asks you out. You don‚Äôt? Tell him the truth, brutal as it might be. Don‚Äôt sugarcoat things because that helps nobody.

These things don‚Äôt just apply to the chase, do they? I‚Äôm not even really sure why they would apply more specifically to guy/girl relationships. All I know is that I see it there more often. However, these thoughts and their ramifications could be generalized to cover any type of relationship with anyone.

entry.title: Tips For Saving Gas
entry.content:
In these current days of high gas prices (currently around $4.50/gallon where I live), it pays to do as much as possible out of what you have. And while I am not ever going to be a hyper-miler, I can at least do as well as I can. (It‚Äôs hard to get superb gas mileage when you drive a truck.)

While I do drive a less than ideal automobile, I am still able to get 20 MPG. And that might not sound too impressive to most people, but for trucks that‚Äôs not bad. But besides that, the tips are still good. They‚Äôre by no means new, though. But I didn‚Äôt just read it on some other site and paste them here. And remember, sometimes it‚Äôs just fine to be Coming Up With It Yourself. [caption id=‚Äù‚Äù align=‚Äùalignright‚Äù width=‚Äù240‚Äù caption=‚ÄùCourtesy of Flickr user Cobalt123‚Äù][/caption]

  1. Minimize Braking - This is of the utmost concern. Some of the other tips could also be generalized to this. Why is braking bad? Well every moment of braking is a moment where energy that was expended by gas is being needlessly lost. That is, you get the most use out of your gas when you‚Äôre not braking at all because all of the energy from the gas is being used to power the vehicle. And while this is not feasible with the traffic laws that we have, it‚Äôs still a true fact.

  2. Coast Into Red Lights - When you see a red light up ahead, don‚Äôt continue with your foot on the accelerator! Why are you in a rush to sit at a red light? Instead, take it easy on the accelerator and ride out your momentum.

  3. Cruise Control Is Your Friend - For periods of driving that are going to be stop-free, utilize that cruise control. The car will consistently apply gas to continue at the speed that the cruise control is set at. And the car will probably do it better than your attempts at keeping your foot steady.

  4. Coast Down Hills - Gravity will accelerate your vehicle down the hill. So put your transmission into neutral (this is more normal with a manual transmission) and let gravity work its magic.

  5. Turn Off The Car - Instead of idling, turn the car off when you know that you‚Äôre going to be sitting for awhile. While most modern cars are not built to constantly be turned on and off (like at every red light), it‚Äôs probably best to turn it off if you‚Äôre waiting for someone to run into the store.

  6. Proper Maintenance - It‚Äôs hard to do your best when your vehicle isn‚Äôt up to snuff. So keep up with those oil changes, regularly inflate those tires, and make sure everything is as the manufacturer intended.

  7. Slow Down - Probably one of the most important, this has numerous benefits besides gas savings including (but not limited to) overall safety.

These seem simple enough. An added bonus for doing all of this is decreased road rage. You‚Äôll care more about what‚Äôs going on with you and your vehicle than you will about how that jerk cut you off. Save a headache, save some money.

entry.title: Coming Up With It Yourself
entry.content:
Have you ever realized that there are so many things that you do not know? I mean, even besides the things that humanity doesn‚Äôt know (e.g. the cure to any of a whole slew of diseases, the details of all of the other planets and galaxies, where Amelia Earhart is), there are things that you just don‚Äôt know like how to program a complex program, how DNA works, how to create a bookcase from a tree, how to cook a perfect turkey for Thanksgiving, and the list goes on endlessly.

So in life, we‚Äôre always learning. You‚Äôve probably heard that it‚Äôs pretty good for you to learn something new everyday. And I concur, that‚Äôs a great thing. Having an open mind, being amazed, willing to be taught. It‚Äôs all swell!

I‚Äôm interested, though, in how there are differences to learning. There is the kind that we learn because someone has taught us (i.e. in the classroom setting at school), but there is also the learning that comes out of a totally different intelligence/mind set. While the former is good, I‚Äôm apt to think that the latter is even better.

Newton, Socrates, Einstein among a few all had to come up with things on their own. They used logic, research, and intuition to arrive at the results that we now know all about today. And while there are many things that have been figured out already, it‚Äôs still pretty good for someone to separately arrive at the correct solution without having been taught it explicitly. At least I think so.

So do you know anyone that solved the Rubik‚Äôs cube without looking at the answer? Yeah me neither. Give the people that figure it out on their own their due.

entry.title: Awkwardness
entry.content:
In a world that advances in technology, conveniences, and all sorts of other benefits, it is comforting to know that some things do not change. No matter where we go, no matter how high we fly, awkwardness will never leave us! Oh hooray!

More than that, it seems like things are getting worse. What with the age of the computer upon us, our social interactions are changing rather dramatically pretty quickly. Children, instead of playing with the other neighborhood kids, will play games online with strangers they‚Äôve never actually met. And while I am not opposed to playing games (I‚Äôve played a game or two myself), you must admit that it is changing things up. Instead of being active, we‚Äôre watching more television. The list goes on and on.

Even beyond childhood, we are maintaining our relationships through this newfangled phenomenon called the Internet. On websites for all sorts of topics and aims, we are interacting with people in a whole new way. We consider people that we‚Äôve never met in real life our friends. We spend countless hours writing on blogs (kind of like this one!). You get the point. I don‚Äôt think that these things are bad in and of themselves, they are bringing our society to a place where social skills are declining.

On a related but slightly different note, is it just me or has the word awkward encroached everyday conversation over the past few years? And somehow, I don‚Äôt think that helps fight against the awkwardness. While it does seem amusing at times, I‚Äôve grown to dislike it quite wholeheartedly. Perhaps it‚Äôs because any amusement is always coming at someone‚Äôs expense. Someone who usually cannot afford to be laughed at. Or maybe it‚Äôs because I‚Äôd much prefer if everyone were comfortable instead. Whatever the reason, awkwardness is no good.

Or am I the only one?

entry.title: Difference Between Childish And Child-Like
entry.content:
I, for one, am very amused by children. Of course, I‚Äôm also amused by a lot of other things. So I guess simply because I‚Äôm amused by something doesn‚Äôt make it noteworthy. And yet here I go writing about what I‚Äôm amused by.

Child-Like

Courtesy of Flickr user Kristi-san

With children, I think that I can break down my amusement to the fact that they are new to the world. They haven‚Äôt lived in society for the years and years that adults have. (Of course, that relates to this comment on a previous post.) So for lack of all of those years of social influence, they are new to the world. They aren‚Äôt jaded because everything is fresh. The ocean is huge, the mountains so tall, and everything is worthy of a question. And in addition to that, they are much more free about doing and saying things. That is, they aren‚Äôt inhibited because they don‚Äôt even know that they should be inhibited. So they‚Äôll run and have fun, pick their nose when they feel a booger, and say what they think about people. Even when it‚Äôs inappropriate.

While I‚Äôm amused by all of this, it‚Äôs also likely because I don‚Äôt have to deal with my own children. Because‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt have any. Yet. Haha but really I‚Äôm positive that it can get old to parents when their kid(s) are acting up endlessly. Oh boy I can‚Äôt even imagine!

Courtesy of Flickr user blondie478

Childish

And while I enjoy this child-like charm, (as the title suggests) I don‚Äôt actually like it when people are acting childish. What‚Äôs the difference? Well in my terms, childish usually applies to those traits of children that are very undesirable. I think of things like throwing temper tantrums, being self-centered, not knowing when to be serious, and other such pleasant attributes. And while children obviously do this, I think that I‚Äôm even more turned off when I see it in people that should know better: adults.

In them, I find it to be such a turn-off. And I‚Äôm not just talking about in girls. When I meet a guy that acts childish, I‚Äôm almost immediately turned off to ever wanting to be friends with him. Childishness just shows (to me) a lack of maturity that is more and more exaggerated the more I‚Äôd expect them to be mature. They say that with age comes wisdom, but that, unfortunately, isn‚Äôt true for everyone.

So it all comes down to this: I want to continually be child-like and grow to never be childish!

entry.title: On Asking A Girl Out
entry.content:
Dating is a frightening proposition. I thought I‚Äôd put together some pointers for those guys who might be thinking about venturing out into the big blue sea.

  1. Scared - That‚Äôs right, girls are scary. They‚Äôre mean. They‚Äôre intimidating. So shy away from them. Ask them out using as little direct interaction as possible (e.g. while chatting online, on their Facebook, over e-mail). They‚Äôll just want to coddle and love you because they can see that you‚Äôre a sensitive soul.

  2. Ask Everyone For Advice - Communal knowledge, right? Ask her friends, her enemies, your friends, your enemies, strangers, and anyone else what you should do before you actually do it. But no matter what, don‚Äôt ask her yet.

  3. Nervous - It‚Äôs not easy. So go ahead and stutter, stumble over your words, and forget what you wanted to say. She‚Äôll understand. It‚Äôs a tough, cold world.

  4. Over Dramatize - Asking out a girl is a big deal. So go all out. Flowers? Of course. Dress up? Sure. Jewelry? Perhaps. Because really, once she says yes to a date, she‚Äôs probably going to say yes to anything else that you ask.

  5. Trick Her - Don‚Äôt even call it a date. Call it ‚Äúhanging out‚Äù or ‚Äúcatching up‚Äù or something similarly ambiguous. That way you can get in under the radar without having to put yourself out there. Because if you put yourself out there, you might get hurt. And that doesn‚Äôt feel good!

  6. Figure Out Everying Before - She‚Äôs gonna say yes anyways. So you have to know what kind of centerpieces you‚Äôre going to have at your banquet. Man she‚Äôs going to look beautiful walking down that aisle towards you, huh?

  7. Don‚Äôt Take No For An Answer - She really wants you. She‚Äôs just playing hard to get. Go get ‚Äòem, Tiger. Even if she gets a restraining order. Even if she never responds to you. Even if she says to get out of her life and never call her again. It‚Äôs all a ploy. Only suckers fall for ploys.

Now you‚Äôre ready, young man. Or old man. Whatever stage of life you are man. You have all of the tools necessary to win the woman of your dreams. Don‚Äôt worry, she‚Äôs gonna love you. Trust me, I can tell about these kinds of things.

entry.title: Pleasantly Surprised > Horribly Disappointed
entry.content:
Expectations. We have them about all kinds of things. Sometimes we base them on our experiences, but more often we seem to base them on our hopes and dreams. We can have them about things like birthdays, get-togethers, and other events. In our mind‚Äôs eye we see people being caring and loving, friendly and jolly. It‚Äôs not always so, is it?

But besides that, we can even have expectations about much more concrete matters. When we sit in the chair, we have that dreamy expectation that the chair will hold up our weight. If that expectation isn‚Äôt met, we sure aren‚Äôt too happy! And so it goes moment by moment with all sorts of things that we encounter.

More recently I‚Äôve noticed how much people do this with things that they don‚Äôt understand. Or rather, I‚Äôve noticed how this comes into play when people are dealing with those things that most of us do not fully understand. Things like televisions, computer programs, and automobiles will all sorely disappoint us when we expect them to work and they do not. But when we don‚Äôt know what to expect, and things work how happy are we?

When we try out a shortcut key and find that some programmer has made sure that shortcut key works aren‚Äôt we pleasantly surprised? Or when we go to a website, make a guess at what to do, aren‚Äôt we glad for whoever made it work just so?

I emphasize the computer software, but it‚Äôs obviously more.

entry.title: Group Friendship
entry.content:
When I think of friendship, I initially think of a relationship between one person and another. They can be all sorts of combination of guys and girls (okay so really there are only 4 combinations if there are 2 people involved). But have you noticed how different everything is when a group is involved?

Imagine, if you will, going into a situation where you‚Äôre trying to get in with a whole group of people. Individually you are able to interact pretty well with them. Conversation is pretty easy, common ground is found, life is good.

But as a whole when you‚Äôre with them things are not well. You are left standing there thinking, ‚ÄúWhat am I doing here?‚Äù You don‚Äôt follow their inside jokes. And you definitely haven‚Äôt known them for as long as they have known each other.

Why the difference? It seems strange to me to be able to be friends with them individually but have trouble with them when they are all a group. But it happens. Related to mob mentality? Who knows, you got me.

entry.title: The Real Better Half
entry.content:
Have you heard people talk about their spouse as ‚Äútheir better half‚Äù? It‚Äôs an interesting (and kind) thing to say. Often it‚Äôs the guy talking about his wife, but not always so. It‚Äôs slightly demeaning towards the ‚Äúlesser half‚Äù (often self-deprecating since that person will say it about themselves) but that‚Äôs supposed to be hidden by the elevation of the spouse.

So my question is, how can both of them be the better half? I really don‚Äôt think that can be the case. I had a talk quite sometime back about this. We talked about different couples that we know, and sad as it was we realized that we could usually think of one person in the relationship who was a better catch. We weren‚Äôt trying to be mean (at least I don‚Äôt remember that being the intention, I think it was just a commentary on things that we saw). Still, it‚Äôs an interesting thought huh?

Think of a couple, and I‚Äôd hazard a guess that you could think that one of them is a bit of a better catch than the other. Now why this might be will obviously change from case to case.

Why did I write this? I don‚Äôt know, I just thought about it all of a sudden. And I thought it was an interesting thought. Don‚Äôt read into it too much or your head will hurt. And nobody likes headaches. Nobody. But do appreciate your other half for what who they are!

entry.title: I Don't Follow Celebrities' Lives
entry.content:
How many people do you know who are more interested and involved in the lives of celebrities than in the lives of those around them? Too many? Yeah, me too.

Who Are They?

In the realm of entertainment, there are actors, musicians, athletes, and people who are nothing else except somehow rich. They all come together at events, walk around the same streets that we do, and have lives that occasionally defy soap operas in their outrageousness. But why are there people who don‚Äôt personally know the celebrities interested in them at all? Is it because they seem to belong to a higher social caste than we? Is it because they are prettier, richer, and more talented than us? Is it because they do things that we wouldn‚Äôt even dream of doing?

My Thoughts

Really I just don‚Äôt know why us common folk are interested in them. All I know is that I see people all over the place who are far more interested in celebrities (who they do not know) than in their friends and family (who they do know). Something doesn‚Äôt seem right about that does it?

I really don‚Äôt think that celebrities are that interesting. I respect their talent, and I‚Äôm definitely not opposed to entertainment. But I don‚Äôt care what kind of a drink they ordered at Starbucks last Wednesday or who was seen schmoozing with who at the hot club in Las Vegas. Nor do I care to use any of my brain to remember any other unnecessarily small fact about them. What kind of a world do we live in where we know the favorite candy of a star and don‚Äôt even know what is really going on with the guy right next to us?

It‚Äôs time to stop immersing ourselves in others‚Äô lives and time to start living our own! (Or at least immerse yourself in someone‚Äôs life who knows that you exist. Who knows, something worthwhile might even come out of it.)

entry.title: Ninjas, Not Pirates
entry.content:
Alright so I don‚Äôt actually know any ninjas. Pirates, though? Perhaps.

Not the pirates that say, ‚ÄúArggh me matey‚Äù or have a peg leg or even have a parrot on their shoulder. That would be cool, but I actually only know pirates in the modern day sense. You know the ones that illegally consume things like music, videos, software, pictures, or any of a whole range of things. Haha I can hear the groans already.

The digital age has made it infinitely more easy to exactly duplicate other content (which is related to why digital things are superior in quality to analog). With this, people have degenerated to outright stealing while not even understanding what they‚Äôre doing. Well I hate to break it to you, but wrongs committed unintentionally are still wrong.

While I have written that I think that Music Piracy Makes People Stupid, this issue is far larger than just music. Music is the best known, probably because it‚Äôs the area that‚Äôs most often violated. It is so much more widespread, though. So let‚Äôs get down to the real issue.

Breaking Down Piracy

  1. Someone creates something for a purpose

  2. Somehow it‚Äôs made available to other people (whether stolen, hacked, copied, or what) outside of the realm of the original purpose

  3. You (or a ‚Äúfriend‚Äù of yours) gets a copy of said good and utilize it

Is that pretty much how it breaks down? Seems to me like the real issue is that the creator/writer/actor/musician/whatever did not intend for those in step 3 to make use of their creation. If I were a computer programmer and wrote a program to sell. And then if someone had illegally hacked my program that I worked to create to sell and gave it away for free, I‚Äôd be piping mad. If you were a photographer and had taken a picture for someone, but someone else had taken it and used it for a totally different purpose, you‚Äôd be up in arms. If you provided services (law, medicine, therapy, teaching, what have you) and someone took your service without providing payment, you‚Äôd see that something was immediately wrong.

So basically, since the creator didn‚Äôt want it (and who hopefully created a bulletproof license or end user agreement), you‚Äôre undermining what they‚Äôre doing. It doesn‚Äôt matter that you could create a digital copy of their song without paying for it and they‚Äôll be none the wiser. Because in actuality, it does affect them. You should have paid them for that song. And you are now a pirate. But you don‚Äôt have to be!

Dealing With This New Ninja World

Is all lost? Far from it. Once you understand what it‚Äôs like to be the one being defrauded, you‚Äôll see that something needs to change. And there is a solution! There are all kinds of answers! Maybe watch things that are actually released by the studios (try out Hulu), actually buy music (if you‚Äôre listening to music you can probably afford to pay for it) or try Amie Street for the whole indie scene, and possibly even catch up on some of my Favorite Open Source Apps.

Or you could just become a real ninja and then you‚Äôd care about arrows, ninja stars, and ninjato rather than swiping versions of old TV shows, Adobe Photoshop, and/or the remix version of Justin Timberlake‚Äôs latest single. :D

entry.title: TiddlyWiki For The World!
entry.content:
You might have heard of a wiki. Then again, you also might not have heard one it. It‚Äôs a method of displaying user-modifiable content. That is, it can be changed by the people looking at it. This is different than things like this blog where I and I alone get to write. The wiki has been gaining notoriety since it allows the collaboration of knowledge, especially over the Internet.

The name wiki gets its name from Ward Cunningham, developer of the very first wiki. It‚Äôs actually Hawaiian in origin (wiki means fast), but you can read more about that at Wikipedia‚Äôs (appropriate since it‚Äôs one of the most well known wikis) page on the wiki.

The TiddlyWiki

So now that we‚Äôve got the foundation knowledge in place, I wanted to share about the TiddlyWiki. (It still strikes me as an amusing name.) It is touted as a personal non-linear personal web notebook. I like to think of it as a central place where you can store whatever you want. It‚Äôs pretty easy to use after some initial adjustment. It is a single html file just like any old webpage.

To use it just open it up in any web browser, and you‚Äôre ready to go. Double-click on things to change them, and you can start creating new tiddlers (entries) and deleting ones that you don‚Äôt need. Saving your changes saves the information into that exact same html file. So all of the data and the framework are contained within a single file. As long as you have a web browser, you can modify your file. And what computer out there doesn‚Äôt have some sort of a web browser nowadays?

This file is the perfect size for a portable usb drive. It starts off empty at about 250KB, but it doesn‚Äôt grow all that quickly since only the new text that is added is stored.

The TiddlyWiki is a method that is open to different uses. And there are many.

Some uses for TiddlyWiki

  • Web Journal - save links and articles that you find online

  • Blog - extremely easy to write and publish (just put the html file on a web server and it‚Äôs published)

  • Personal Journal - just have the file with you wherever you are, and it‚Äôll be safe from prying eyes

  • Collaborate on projects - one person can write and the changes will be instantly available for anyone else to see

There are many ways to store information. You could write it on paper, you could just remember everything, you could use a Microsoft Word document, whatever. So here are some reasons why you‚Äôd use a TiddlyWiki instead of one of those other methods.

Advantages of TiddlyWiki

  • Basic tags (which allow you to quickly see all entries with a particular tag)

  • Quick searching as you type into the search box

  • Self-contained (it‚Äôs a single file)

  • Portable (I guess that‚Äôs always relative, but it‚Äôs small in size)

  • Interactive feel

Server-side Implementations

Personally I‚Äôve been using a version of this that‚Äôs on my server. I tried a couple of different products, but MiniTiddlyServer (Update: MiniTiddlyServer is not deprecated so you will need to figure out another way) was the easiest and most straightforward for my PHP-enabled server. All I needed to do was download the zip file, put it onto my server, and off I went! Update: Check out my own TiddlyWiki

For those without their own server, TiddlySpot seems like a reasonable free solution. *[html]: Hyper Text Markup Language *[usb]: Universal Serial Bus

entry.title: 200th Post

Courtesy of Flickr user Verdesam

entry.title: Age - It's Just A Number
entry.content:
We, as people, have a love/hate relationship with one of the things that is constantly changing: our age. Sometimes we want to get older, and sometimes we will do everything that we can to reduce it. But we really have no control over it, do we?

It seems as if all of this starts early in life. As we are going through the different grades in school, there is a marked distinction between students who are in different grades. Granted, this is all rather necessary because children generally mature and progress according to how old they are. So it makes sense in that situation. But the lasting influence seems to be that we feel comfortable with just people our own age.

Relationships

This effect can often be seen in the arena of relationships. Why is it that many of my friends who are girls will not even think about dating a younger guy? Is it because younger guys is not be great and worthy of her? Is it because they (the girls) are somehow more mature because they are a couple of years (sometimes a couple of months) older? I doubt it. Why do my guy friends only look for girls that are younger than them? And why is there a floor limit such that they won‚Äôt even consider girls younger than their specified age? There are a lot of questions, and there aren‚Äôt that many answers. All I know is that it all doesn‚Äôt make much sense. People limit themselves by not looking for the things that really matter, the essence and characteristics of a person. Then they complain that they can‚Äôt find anyone. And that‚Äôs just not right, is it?

Social Aspects

People age. That‚Äôs the truth. And it seems like as that happens the reality of death is more apparent. The chances become greater (on any particular day since the actual chances that you will die are 100%), and that seems to have lend itself to the general notion that young is better. Even more than that unspoken tendency is that socially we have come to praise the young as vibrant and beautiful.

On the other hand, people who are getting older can always attest that they are getting wiser. It‚Äôs true, they should be getting wiser anyways. They just have more experience, and those with experience know that it counts. Of course, those who lack it do not think that it counts for very much. I know, I‚Äôve been/am still there.

Conclusion

But I say that it‚Äôs so much more important to be young at heart. Of people that I‚Äôve met, young and old, I find myself consistently being convinced that being young at heart is truly the way that I want to go. I don‚Äôt want to lose the awe of a child looking at the huge expanse of the night sky or discovering something for the first time. No amount of time or social constructs can take that away. Whatever you do, don‚Äôt be proud of your age sheerly because of your age. That would make you Proud Of Nothing, wouldn‚Äôt it?

So really there are 2 ways that you can deal with age:

  1. Wine - get tastier and more valuable with age

  2. Cheese - get moldy!

Haha I know, I‚Äôm just good at making up strikingly accurate analogies. You don‚Äôt need to tell me twice. No really, you don‚Äôt.

entry.title: Being A Groomsman
entry.content:
So this past weekend, I got the privilege of being in a wedding party for the first time. And I must say, it was quite nice!

I wanted to write this down partly for myself, just so that I can remember it all.

Starting the day before the rehearsal some of the groomsmen hung out with Daniel, the groom. It wasn‚Äôt too outrageous at all.

Then the day of the rehearsal (the day before the actual wedding) was quite busy. Rental car, drove up ~60 miles to the church (in LA) for the rehearsal. Got there in time (even with workday traffic). Fun rehearsal! For some reason it seemed pretty amusing. (Oh and I might have tested out the sanctuary to see how my laugh would echo. And other people might have told me to not dare laugh the day of the wedding. :P) Rehearsal lunch. Food was good, and the conversation was fairly flowing. Hotel. The hotel messed up. Unhappiness. Ah oh well. Go-karts. Better at it than I thought. (I guess that even though I can rant On Driving, I might very well have an aggressive driver in me!) Got 2nd out of our group (thanks a lot Mike haha). Hm where is my trophy? Dinner with Daniel‚Äôs family. Late, but it worked out. Sat with some of his extended family and another groomsman. Got to hear about New Mexican food and their amazing miracle chili sauce. (I‚Äôve never tried it, but I‚Äôd be very willing at this point!) Hotel. Get ready for sleep. Gifts from groom. Talk. Sleep.

Up at 6:30 AM (it was a 10:30 AM wedding) to get ready. Out of the hotel by 8 AM. Do random stuff at the church and sit around looking good for a couple of hours. Walk down the aisle. Stand. Stand. Feet hurt. Stand. And done! Get out of there, help with more random stuff. Reception. Kiss kiss. See old friends from college. Nice. Good lunch. Real nice. Slideshow. Oh sweet they put me in it more than once. Drive back down to pick up my car from the groom‚Äôs place, and that‚Äôs a wrap!

I enjoyed my time being a part of their wedding. I‚Äôm glad that I at least got to be in one! Haha I think that I‚Äôm probably good in terms of wedding experiences. That is I don‚Äôt need to be a part of another one. Except as groom. That‚Äôs one experience that I‚Äôm pretty positive that I want!

entry.title: My Reminder System
entry.content:
Remembering something is usually a case of you did or you didn‚Äôt. I‚Äôve often found it amusing for things like birthdays when people will say that they remembered, but they just didn‚Äôt say anything about it. Really‚Ä¶well that‚Äôs hard to imagine.

The thing is, some people have better memories than others. Everyone is different and is able to remember things in different ways. Laugh if you must, but I remember wanting a photographic memory like Cam Jansen when I was a kid. Then I could rapidly flip through books and not need to study! How wonderful that would have been! But alas, my dreams did not come true. Even now I often wish for a better memory.

But just as remembering something is pretty binary (i.e. you did or you didn‚Äôt), those of us lacking in the memory department have to make do with what we have. Otherwise we will be mocked. Who will mock, I do not know. All I know is that mocking will occur.

3 Memory Aids That I Use:

  1. Remember The Milk

(RTM for short)

Besides having a pretty amusing name, this is a website whose sole purpose is to create TODO lists. It‚Äôs refreshing for a website to be so singular in its purpose in this day of do-everything-until-we-take-over-your-life websites. In any case, I initially signed up for an account on the site, thought it was cool, and promptly did not hardly ever use it because visiting another site everyday wasn‚Äôt too practical.

But then they developed a Firefox extension that changed that up! They developed an extension for placing an RTM pane whenever a Gmail tab is opened! It maintains the overall look and feel of gmail so you (or at least I) don‚Äôt feel like it‚Äôs out of place at all. Since I much more often have a browser tab open for Gmail, I was much more able to use the service. And I have. And it‚Äôs great!

The concept is nothing new, you just put in due dates. But since it‚Äôs in front of my face at least once a day (since I check my e-mail once a day), it‚Äôs actually useful. And it‚Äôs on a remote server so I don‚Äôt need to worry about losing it or keeping different lists in sync.

So there are 2 ways to use this baby:

* [Gmail for RTM extension](http://www.rememberthemilk.com/services/gmail/) * [RTM website](http://www.rememberthemilk.com)

Either will do, just do.

  1. Phone calendar

Okay so I don‚Äôt have a smart phone. But that doesn‚Äôt mean that my phone is dumb! (Ha‚Ä¶ha‚Ä¶)

But almost all phones nowadays have some sort of calendar feature. And that‚Äôs fine and dandy for checking what the date is. But there is often also the ability to schedule events. So I use my phone (a Motorola, by the way) and put in reminders for certain things that I need to get done.

This is especially useful when I‚Äôm out and about. Often my phone is one of the few things that I‚Äôll carry with me. I could actually text message a reminder to RTM which is cool. But I‚Äôll be honest, I‚Äôm cheap when it comes to text messaging. And Verizon charges $.15 per message. For the amount of reminders that I put in for myself, that could get pricey. Haha laugh if you want, but the calendar reminders are free.

Google Calendar

Calendars have been around for ages. The print versions are still quite popular and understandably so. But as computer usage becomes more and more prevalent, we are transferring much of the things that we do in tangible form to things that we can do through using the computer.

Personally I use the Google calendar, but really there are many such applications floating around. I figure that I already have a Gmail account, so why not. (Of course, this line of reasoning sounds that in my post Google‚Äôs Taking Over The World‚Ä¶And I Don‚Äôt Like It.)

Anyways, a nice feature of Google calendar is that I can have it e-mail me before the event occurs. I don‚Äôt use the application everyday, but awhile back I input all of my friends‚Äô birthdays. Now it will e-mail me the day before someone‚Äôs birthday, so I‚Äôll never egregiously forget a friend‚Äôs birthday!

Granted, it‚Äôd be better if I just remembered. It would show that I care more. It‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt care. It‚Äôs just that I don‚Äôt want to make a mistake! It‚Äôs my failsafe, if you will.

* [Google Calendar website](http://www.google.com/calendar)

Do you have other tips for fellow forgetful fellows (or gals)?

entry.title: Yelp Like You Love It
entry.content:
One thing that the Internet is an amazing tool for is the ability to draw on collective knowledge. By being so easy to reach more people, we are able to better understand things. We can, as a society, collaborate and pool our individual pieces of the puzzle to form a more completely picture. I‚Äôm getting away from myself with the metaphors. Anyways, I think that one of the more useful applications of this for me is yelp.com.

Basically I like to eat, and yelp helps me do that well.

So yelp isn‚Äôt at all a new website, and I kind of think that a lot of people have already heard of and/or used it before. But it doesn‚Äôt matter because you know what? I get to post whatever I want to since this is my site. :)

I meant to post this quite some time back, but I‚Äôve been sitting on this post for a really long time. And the only reason is because I wanted to upload a picture before I posted a link to my yelp page. How lame is that? How hard is it to get a profile picture nowadays? It took me all of 2 minutes to accomplish that strenuous task.

Personally I‚Äôve found this site to be pretty helpful, and I think that it‚Äôs worthwhile to me to be involved with it. The premise is that reviews will be made by people that actually go to different establishments. While I use the site mainly for food, they do have reviews of everything from shopping to entertainment to health centers.

The most useful thing to me seems to be that you can limit your search by location and see a map of where these places are in relation to where you are. Because even though I might be looking for some amazing food, I‚Äôm not exactly willing to drive 50 miles to get said amazing food into my mouth. But 5 miles for some pretty reasonably tasty food? Yeah I could go for that. You can also further filter the results based on more specific criteria such as food ethnicity.

Running off of a 5-star system, it‚Äôs easy to quickly see how popular a restaurant is. For more in depth (and often rather interesting) reviews, there are the user comments. These usually range from the short and not-too-helpful to the long and exceedingly useful. Many reviewers will describe their entire meal experience, and it helps you get a feel for what a restaurant is like without actually having been there. Sometimes you can find very useful menu suggestions in the comments as well. To reward reviewers, you can designate their comment as one that you thought was either cool, useful, or funny.

There is even a social aspect to this site as you can add friends on it. I‚Äôm not sure if that‚Äôs something that I‚Äôm really going for. According to yelp, I currently have no friends. Haha let‚Äôs hope that‚Äôs only on yelp!

My own page, with my reviews and info, is derekwong.yelp.com. Check out some places that I‚Äôve been to, but more importantly let‚Äôs all help each other out by supporting quality establishments. You‚Äôll be thankful that next time you‚Äôre looking for a place to go to on your hot date. Because we all know that the key to the hot date is the food. Personality? Eh. Charm? Blah. Looks? Well you can‚Äôt help that anyways.

entry.title: Profanity Without Using Curse Words
entry.content:
Profanity is often used in society in order to express discontent. From mild, momentary displeasure to extreme fury, humans make use of a seemingly defined set of off-limit words to express their emotions. Often these words reference things which would generally be considered better left unspoken of.

What is profanity really? Apparently there are 5 types of swearing (according to Steven Pinker‚Äôs The Stuff of Thought: Language as a Window into Human Nature which I found a reference to in the Wikipedia article on profanity):

Photo courtesy of Flickr user Found Drama
  1. Dysphemistic - Opposite of euphemism. Force listener to think about negative thing
  2. Abusive - Abuse, intimidate, or insult others
  3. Idiomatic - Refer to (but do not explicitly mention) something in order to arouse interest, be macho/cool, or express to peers that the setting is informal.
  4. Emphatic - Emphasize what is being said (pretty self-explanatory)
  5. Cathartic - Rid oneself of negative feelings by outwardly expressing it

I can see how all of these are accurate descriptions for how profanity is used. It‚Äôs very interesting to study profanity and how it comes about. How it is sociological in a sense because profanity in our language is different from profanity in other languages (even taking into account translation). That‚Äôs not the issue.

The issue is that profanity comes out of your mouth much more than you‚Äôd like to admit. I feel your pain, it comes out of mine more than I‚Äôd like to admit, too.

In fact, I‚Äôve told people before that I do not cuss. And I‚Äôm absolutely correct in a strict sense of the term. I don‚Äôt use those words that society has impressed upon me as being profane. In fact, I don‚Äôt feel like I need to use profanity in order to express myself. I do feel the same emotions that my cursing brothers feel. (Okay I don‚Äôt actually have blood brothers, but I mean it in the mankind term.) And yet I don‚Äôt see that it‚Äôs too necessary. Am I aghast when I hear it? Not extremely so. Well I‚Äôm not with those from whom I expect nothing better. Some people are held to a higher standard, but I digress.

So I don‚Äôt cuss. But the thing is that I‚Äôll cuss in spirit. I‚Äôll use nice versions like ‚Äúdarn‚Äù, ‚Äúcrap‚Äù, and ‚Äúshoot‚Äù instead of the usual fare. But does that make it any better? No, I‚Äôm beginning to think that it does not matter much at all. Even though the words are different and less offensive to the ear according to society, the usage shows that my mouth is still overflowing with what is in my heart. And I can see that all is not right in that region of my chest. I‚Äôm not as loving or as good as I profess.

Ah if only the distance between my head and my heart weren‚Äôt so far.

entry.title: Difference Between Nerd, Geek, And Dork
entry.content:
The common thought is that nerds, geeks, and dorks are one and the same. However, I don‚Äôt think so. Semantics, shemantics, you say.

Although they seem very similar, I‚Äôm gonna have to go with a ‚Äúyeah I don‚Äôt think so.‚Äù Looking them up online doesn‚Äôt provide definitive results, but I am still convinced. (Looking them up online does prove amusing because apparently the first definition of nerd is ‚Äúa stupid, irritating, ineffectual, or unattractive person.‚Äù Stinks to be called unattractive in the dictionary.)

First off, the most important thing to note with any of these terms is that they can have both negative and positive connotations. I think that it mainly depends on your self-awareness. So if someone calls you a nerd, and you think of yourself as a nerd, then it‚Äôs not so bad. However, if you think that you‚Äôre a cool guy and you get called a nerd, all is not right with the world. As in many things in life, the failing of some expectation will result in your disappointment. And sadness. And low self-esteem. You get the point.

Alright so back to the matter at hand. (Cue ‚ÄúNothin‚Äô But A G Thang‚Äù! Hm I thought there was a rap song with ‚Äúback to the matter at hand,‚Äù but I can‚Äôt find the song, let alone one that I could listen to in order to verify that. So‚Ä¶you get a small lame comment about how I tried and failed to remember a rap song of old.) Okay back to it, really now.

Here is the breakdown of the different types (at least in my mind):

  • Nerd - intelligent, industrious, understands things
Courtesy of Flickr user Matt Ryall

By day I‚Äôm a software engineer. (By night a superhero, but that‚Äôs another matter.) So I‚Äôm obviously a little biased if I give a good definition for a word and also remind everyone that it can describe me. But whatever, it‚Äôs what I actually think.

Some computer programmers (but by no means all of them) generally tend to be of the sort of people that want to delve deeper into understanding issues than others would. They want to truly understand how something works rather than just settling for using the end product. In the case of computer programming, while everyone else is content with looking at websites, using applications, and generally enjoying the products of the computer programming, the programmers themselves are working to create those products. And if they‚Äôre not creating them, then they‚Äôre trying to understand them.

Some of them might not be like that, but those are the kind that will end up not being very good at what they do. Those are the ones that do not have Professional Integrity. They‚Äôll also end up being your boss, but more on that later.

In a general sense, nerds can be from all different backgrounds. But I think that they can generally be described as someone who is willing to study and do the work in order to learn the stuff. I‚Äôm not quite sure that someone who is naturally gifted with intelligence but who doesn‚Äôt utilize it can be categorized as a nerd. No, I take that back. They cannot be categorized as a nerd. They‚Äôre just smart and lazy. Really, how much worse can you get? I think that most people would rather be dumb and hard-working than smart and lazy.

Courtesy of Flickr user Pragmagraphr

Nerds can often be found in libraries, hunched over books, or wondering aloud about their surroundings. ‚ÄúNerd‚Äù seems to be used most often in a complimentary way when describing others.

Someone can very well be a nerd, and you wouldn‚Äôt be able to tell from the outside appearance. The stereotype of the nerd is a skinny guy with glasses and a pocket protector. But something that I learned in college is that the surfer dude can be just as much of a nerd as the stereotype. He just hides it better. Much better.

The unfortunately sad thing about the term nerd is that it doesn‚Äôt just apply to those that work hard. They actually have to be good at whatever it is that they‚Äôre doing, whether school or work. Someone that works hard but who still is not as successful is just that, a hard worker. (Of course, a hard worker is still better than a smart lazy person.)

Basically, nerds rule. They‚Äôre even better when they know that they‚Äôre nerds and are not socially inept.

  • Geek - Interested in things that others are not interested in, know a lot about their interests, but usually do not understand underlying principles

So I mentioned before when talking about nerds that there are computer programmers who will end up not being very good at programming. Unlike the more kindly description that I have above about nerdy computer programmers, these geek programmers fall into another category. And yeah, that category is lower.

Courtesy of Flickr user ClausM

In their work they will do things that they have no idea the meaning of. Unfortunately, they will sometimes correctly stab in the dark and get something right. That will only reinforce their thinking that their way is working. Stumbling, somehow they manage to get others to help them so that they eventually finish whatever it is that they‚Äôre doing.

I generally liken geeks more to IT (Information Technology) type of people rather than computer programmers. These are the people that know how to use a computer very well, but who would not be able to program ‚ÄúHello World.‚Äù They can fiddle with and modify settings and properties to no end. They love computers, but they don‚Äôt actually know how a computer works. Of course, not all IT folks are like this. In my experience, it just seems like they can more generally be described this way.

Even beyond the IT people, geeks can be interested in a wide spectrum of topics. They will often be interested in technology-related things. I think that it‚Äôs because not everyone understands these things. Since geeks do not have skills in some areas of life, they want to have an area of expertise where others could not compare to them.

So yes, geeks are the types of people that are not only interested in Star Trek, but who will also dress up to go to the premiere. They‚Äôll also buy collector cards, read forums online, and read every single book about Star Trek. Obsess much? Yes they will. But you don‚Äôt know where the Klingon Galaxy is located relative to our current position in space, do you??

Geeks come in all shapes and sizes. Of course, those are usually the odd shapes and sizes. They are generally not as hard to spot as the nerds because of their disregard for what others think of them. Their clothes don‚Äôt match, and they might occasionally offend others with their insufficient personal hygiene.

Still, geeks have their strong points. They are dedicated to what they like. They don‚Äôt really care that much what other people think about them. And they generally rule the Internet. However, they don‚Äôt rule sports, social situations, or tangible environments. They‚Äôre awkward in situations that they‚Äôre not accustomed to (like the aforementioned) and tend to do things that give away their geekdom like go on incessantly about their favorite topic when the real topic is something entirely different.

  • Dork - Foolish, stupid, clumsy

There‚Äôs not really any two-ways about it, ‚Äúdork‚Äù is not too good of a term. Obviously if someone is using it in an endearing fashion, it‚Äôs not too bad. And if someone says it about themselves, it‚Äôs usually in an amusing and self-deprecating way. But the term itself doesn‚Äôt have too much positive spin on it.

Courtesy of Flickr user Cranky Media Guy

Dorks are the type of people who will do silly things. That‚Äôs not to say that they‚Äôll necessarily be the ones making grand gestures to make people laugh. But they are comfortable enough with themselves to do things like put a ‚Äúdork‚Äù box on their head and laugh at themselves.

If the dork is aware that they are a dork, then it‚Äôs funny. If they‚Äôre not aware, then it‚Äôs painful to watch such a socially uncomfortable person try to get by. Now I‚Äôm not sure whether they feel awkward or if they feel at ease with themselves in those situations. All I know is that it‚Äôs sometimes hard for me to watch.

Once again, there are good traits in the dork. The self-aware dork is able to not take themselves too seriously. They are able to do what they want without caring about others‚Äô opinions. And even the dork who is not self-aware is able to make others feel more comfortable simply because of their silliness. Nobody feels the fool when they‚Äôre next to someone who is more foolish.

The funny thing is, I‚Äôm all of these things.

So what can you do with this knowledge?¬† I have no idea, but here are some fun items to get while you figure it out:

  • xkcd book (Vol. 0)
  • All kinds of xkcd clothes (a few favorites)
  • Big old rimmed glasses
  • Fanny pack

entry.title: Package Waste
entry.content:
I don‚Äôt like how it‚Äôs impossible to get every last bit of semi-liquid type substances out of their container. Even more than that, though, it disappoints me that this slight irritation happens so often!

So as you probably know (or at least can guess from my blog‚Äôs name) that I‚Äôm Chinese. The stereotype is that Chinese people specifically (and Asian people in general) are a little bit stingy. Now, there are quite a lot of times that I can heartily agree that this stereotype has roots in reality. Maybe it‚Äôs because in China everyone has to fight for their own rights and properties since there are so many people vying for the limited resources. Ah communism at its best.

But another thing that you should know is that I‚Äôm, in general, not very Chinese. Now what does that mean? Well I don‚Äôt even speak the language, let alone act out the whole stereotype. I am, for all intents and purposes, completely American. Nevertheless, I do have a frugal side to me. (I mean, I did share 3 Little Tips To Save before.) And that frugal Chinese side of me doesn‚Äôt like that products are placed into packages that don‚Äôt allow me to utilize all that I‚Äôve paid for!

There are just so many of these items that we use! Don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm talking about? Well what about:

  • yogurt

  • mayonnaise

  • toothpaste

  • shampoo

  • lotion

And that‚Äôs just to name a few! There are obviously many other things that could fall into this category. One would think that after so many years of production and perfecting the whole process, a better solution would have been reached. But no. All we get are cheap gadgets like the toothpaste clip that will ensure that as much paste as possible is pushed towards the opening. Ah!

What‚Äôs a society to do? It‚Äôs time for a change. It‚Äôs time for a revolution.

entry.title: Lock The Stall Door
entry.content:
There are some things that happen in life that cause you to become speechless. For some, this happens more often than for others. For me, it just happened. What in the world do you say when you walk into a stall and someone is sitting on the toilet doing their business?

Wait a second, something is not right. Oh yeah, I‚Äôm not supposed to go into a stall when another person is already in there.

  1. ‚ÄúYou forgot to lock the door, you ninny.‚Äù

  2. ‚ÄúSurprise! I‚Äôm here!‚Äù

  3. ‚ÄúHow are those TPS reports going?‚Äù

  4. ‚ÄúAh ha, THAT‚ÄôS where the smell was coming from!‚Äù

  5. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs that crossword puzzle going for you?‚Äù

  6. ‚ÄúWhoa‚Ä¶you know that‚Äôs not normal.‚Äù

  7. ‚ÄúRoom in here for another?‚Äù

entry.title: Get My Name Right
entry.content:
I know what it feels like to be unknown, and I don‚Äôt like it. I‚Äôm talking about people getting my name wrong.

Generally I actually do think that I‚Äôm a bit forgettable. That might sound sad, but it‚Äôs the truth. I don‚Äôt make terribly flattering first impressions. That‚Äôs just how it has been. It‚Äôs gotten better, I think, as I‚Äôve grown into my skin, but it‚Äôs probably fairly true still.

Courtesy of flickr user Oxygen

Names are our unique key to life. It has a bit of our heritage in our surname, and it is the first gift that we are given. It‚Äôs a marking that we will have for our lifetime (that is unless we legally change it at some point). And it‚Äôs how we are known. Life would be different if we had a different name.

Considering all of this, it‚Äôs not exactly pleasant when someone forgets your name. It makes you feel (and probably accurately so) that you‚Äôre not important enough to be remembered by the one who forgot. Nobody likes to be reminded of how unimportant they are. Everyone wants to be special and being known is just the first step.

There have been a few instances where I‚Äôve noticed this occurring to me. Thankfully it‚Äôs not exactly stuff that‚Äôs affected me, but it‚Äôs still noteworthy because I‚Äôm sure that there are many out there who wouldn‚Äôt take kindly to this happening to them.

At work we had a going away brunch for someone, and people from all different departments were there. As I was standing there, someone was loudly saying someone else‚Äôs name and looking at me. Now usually, it is a very bad idea to respond to these greetings in your direction that might not necessarily be for you. You know the wave from strangers who are actually waving to the guy right behind you. That kind of thing. In any case, I was not responding to this girl because I figured she must have been trying to get someone else‚Äôs attention. She eventually turns to her friend and says, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not responding to me, I guess.‚Äù Then she gets even closer to me and says this other guy‚Äôs name.

Granted I was sideways so she only had a profile view. I turned to her, and I said that I was not who she thought I was. She realized her mistake and fell silent. That‚Äôs right, lady. You‚Äôre wrong.

The same day as the first example, I was walking by someone‚Äôs desk, and he said, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up, ‚Äî‚Äì?‚Äù This other name was another Asian guy in our department. I knew that he was talking to me because nobody else was around, and I said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Derek, not ‚Äî‚Äî.‚Äù

The bad thing is that he does know the difference between us. We traveled for quite a few days together! And we work in the same department! This one was probably a more honest slip of the tongue, but I still thought it pretty amusing considering that it was the same day. To exacerbate the matter, the same guy cc‚Äôd me on an e-mail and spelled my name Derrick. And we‚Äôve been working together for about 15 months. Lovely, just lovely.

So another instance where forgetting a name can be bad is if you remember the other person‚Äôs name, and they do not remember your name. Bad beans. If you both forget, it‚Äôs acceptable. But if you both do not, all is not right.

So I recently went to a fellowship group again after not going for a couple of months. I remembered a few of the people‚Äôs name because of talking to them or because I secretly actually knew stuff about them. Haha creepy as that might sound, it was more like an ‚ÄúI know that they asked my friend out, but they don‚Äôt me‚Äù kind of deal. In any case, it was no good for me to remember their names since they forgot mine. Boo hoo.

So basically we all need to learn these things:

  • We need better memories

  • All Asians do not look alike

  • Get more confidence so you don‚Äôt care if people forget your name because you‚Äôre above that

  • Don‚Äôt respond to women who are yelling, no good can ever come of it

entry.title: Proud Of Nothing
entry.content:
People will get proud over anything. Even those that have nothing to be proud of will somehow find themselves becoming proud of something. It‚Äôs rather amazing really. When you stop to think about it, none of us really has anything to be proud of.

There are a wide variety of things that pride is claimed. I think that the most ridiculous ones are those things over which we have no control. Here are some of my favorites:

  1. Nationalism/Patriotism/Geographic devotion

This is rampant around the world and throughout all of time. However, it‚Äôs rather silly to be proud of where you come from simply because that‚Äôs where you came from, don‚Äôt you think? Sure it‚Äôs a great way to connect to people when you first meet them, but how much do you really have to be proud of if you grew up somewhere? Usually it‚Äôs not too much.

I think that perhaps the only thing that I could understand about this is if one had to grow up in a difficult environment. It shapes a person to be able to grow up in that type of surrounding. But for all of those people who are proud of where they grew up, what country they were born in, what their heritage is, and so on, you better rethink it. Because you had no hand in that.

And to think that people get into wars over this issue all of the time is mind boggling. You mean to tell me that you hate that guy because of where he was born? But he had no control over that, he didn‚Äôt choose to be born there!

  1. Height

Have you met people who were proud of their height? I think that might be one of the most ridiculous things ever because you absolutely have no control over your height. You can lose or gain weight, have plastic surgery to fix your looks, and any number of things to modify your physical appearance.

But what can you do about your height? Diddly squat, I do believe. Unless you have that limb lengthening surgery. Anyways, once again you have no control over how tall you are/will be. You can hope for good genes, but it‚Äôs much more impressive to just be able to deal with those that you‚Äôve been given. And better yet, it‚Äôs impressive to be able to overlook (no pun intended) it in others.

  1. Discovering Music Artists/Clothing Brands

I mean really? You‚Äôre going to be proud of the fact that you found out about a band before anyone else did? You had no hand in their success. You‚Äôre not playing bass or pounding those drums for them. All you did was take a little listen.

Okay sure, it‚Äôs very nice that you spend the time and try out different artists than the popular fare served up to the masses. Maybe you even spent a little bit of money to try them out. But when the band becomes popular, if you find yourself bringing up the fact that you listened to them for years, I‚Äôll have you know that I think that you‚Äôre a lame-o.

Same thing goes for clothing brands (and probably a slew of other things). You‚Äôre not making the clothes, you‚Äôre just buying a sweater. $20 bucks. You daredevil you.

  1. Age

Whether you‚Äôre young or old, what can you really say about your age? It won‚Äôt change a lick no matter what you do. You can lie about it, you can deceive others by changing your appearance, but this is an absolute in this world that you have no control over.

I think it‚Äôs so interesting when people see their age as something to be proud of. In the past I‚Äôve seen it because people think that they‚Äôre immediately wiser for the simple fact that they‚Äôve lived more days. I grant them that it‚Äôs generally true that wisdom comes with age. But isn‚Äôt that usually more like decades of experience?

Growing up in school, I was meeting people with years or less worth more days who thought that they were somehow wiser than I. I thought (and still do) think that is just ludicrous. It‚Äôs like they can‚Äôt find anything to be proud of so they just grasp for something that nobody can change. How about instead of doing that we go out and actually gain some of that useful wisdom by getting a life, huh?

  1. Salvation

Well I‚Äôm a Christian. Maybe you knew that, maybe you didn‚Äôt. Now you do. Anyways, I‚Äôve got a bone to pick with those people that speak of their salvation with an air of superiority, as if they did anything at all except believe. This might stir up the pot a little bit, but there isn‚Äôt much that separates you from that unsaved guy next to you. I boast in Jesus Christ, too, but He did the work, not I. I just said, ‚ÄúYes, I‚Äôll believe.‚Äù

entry.title: Building Relationships
entry.content:
I‚Äôve come to notice recently that relationships are very similar to a house of cards.

Alright they‚Äôre not always like a house of cards, they very much can be in certain ways. When one is just starting to get to know another person, there is a lot of feeling out in conversation. Both people need to be talking and questions need to be asked. This is some basic knowledge about relationships.

Photo courtesy of flickr user privatenobby

Almost more importantly than how to build a relationship, though, is how easy it is to destroy it. It‚Äôs important to know how relationships can be destroyed because that is the only way that it can be avoided. It seems to me that I can very easily liken the building of a relationship to the creation of a house of cards. For both creations it takes far greater time and effort to build them up than it takes to destroy them. With the house of cards all you need is an inadvertent swipe of the hand or even an exhaled breath to cause it all to come tumbling down. With relationships (whether friendships, romantic relationships, or otherwise) a simple outburst, a snide comment, a hurtful action, or even an ill-advised joke can undo all of the time and effort involved in developing a relationship.

I think that whether you‚Äôve been on the receiving end of a one of these relationship destroyers or whether you‚Äôve dished one out yourself, you know that they‚Äôre almost never worth it. Unfortunately I think that most of the time people don‚Äôt even know what they‚Äôve done. They can‚Äôt see it because it‚Äôs not visual, it‚Äôs within the person. Take a look around and you‚Äôll see cards everywhere.

entry.title: Music Remedies Menial Tasks
entry.content:

entry.title: Imagine A World Without: Fire
entry.content:
Have you ever thought about how life can be different? Well the other day I was thinking about what our world would be like without our friend fire. And a very different world it would be.

It sure would be cold. Haha and Bear Grylls wouldn‚Äôt be able to teach us that fire is so important to survive in the wild. Hopefully he would still eat crazy things on his show, though.

But once you get past the fact that we‚Äôd all be shivering perhaps you think that it wouldn‚Äôt be so bad because we could have electricity to warm us. Electric heaters are all over the place, and they certainly do not require fire. So we wouldn‚Äôt freeze to death and perhaps people could still live in Alaska.

However, there are many things that we would not have in our use. We wouldn‚Äôt be able to have:

  1. Cars - That sure would change our world, wouldn‚Äôt it? They‚Äôre currently needed because gasoline engines use sparks to create a small combustion that, through a series of gears and mechanical parts, powers the wheels. Granted I guess a spark isn‚Äôt exactly fire. However I‚Äôm assuming that we would have gotten nowhere close to a spark if we didn‚Äôt have fire.

  2. Food - How in the world would we cook it? Would we be eating lots and lots of sushi? Maybe just raw vegetables? How animalistic!

  3. Trains - Perhaps you don‚Äôt think that losing trains is any great loss. I mean who really rides trains nowadays anyways? Well lest you forget, trains still carry vast amounts of goods across land. They‚Äôre often supposed to be more efficient than trucks because of their fixed rail.

  4. Swords - How will the ninjas work? They‚Äôll be put out of a job. But seriously, there would be no metallurgy as we know it because the metal needs to be shaped after being heated‚Ä¶by fire. So kiss your katana goodbye.

Fire has got to get a mention in the race for best creation ever. Without it we‚Äôd be a hungry bunch of people eating who knows what. And we‚Äôd all be biking everywhere. Well that would be a good thing because then we wouldn‚Äôt be obese. But everyone would be walking around sweaty and smelly. And to add insult to injury, everything metal would be ugly and rough. Put a chunk of that in your ear and see how you like it. Makes one a little more thankful for the things that we take for granted, does it not? Still it‚Äôs kind of fun to have an imagination!

entry.title: A Quote About True Friends
entry.content:
Friends are such an integral part of life. They are there for us to have fun, to share with, and to truly live our lives with. And, just as in many of our relationships in life, they can be a source of pain. I‚Äôm not necessarily saying that I feel that right now, but that doesn‚Äôt discount the truth in the statement, does it?

People have a tendency to let relationships deteriorate. It takes constant effort and a willing heart to maintain those relationships that might otherwise fall by the way side. Being a couple of years out of college I can so easily see how much my friendships and relationships with a lot of my friends has done so. It‚Äôs on the one hand tragic but on the other hand just a fact of life.

Wow I really was thinking that I need some lighter-hearted posts. Oh well.

So here‚Äôs my quote, tell me what you think.

True friends do not prove themselves in the exciting moments of life. Hardships and joyous occasions are not where they‚Äôre found.

No, the proving ground of a true friend is in the mundane and dull moments of the everyday life. -Derek Wong

Well I‚Äôve actually thought about this before, but I had never gotten around to find out whether or not someone else has said it before I have. As usual, someone probably did. But it‚Äôd take too long to try to find and properly give them credit. So if someone else happens upon it, I‚Äôll gladly give someone else the credit.

Basically all I mean is that it‚Äôs so easy to feel close to people when they‚Äôre going through things that are interesting. But life consists of only a few of those moments. It‚Äôs so much nicer to have friends and people around you that actually want to hear about the days when life isn‚Äôt as exciting or exceptionally interesting. I feel like I‚Äôve said that before, but it must have been in conversation rather than on my blog. Granted it‚Äôs even better to just be interesting all of the time, but I digress.

entry.title: A Quote For Regret And Rejection
entry.content:
Sometimes we have to choose our poison, don‚Äôt we? It‚Äôs not always blue pill or red pill, sometimes it‚Äôs bad and worse. In any case, I feel like I must have heard this quote, but I can‚Äôt seem to find its source online. I think that it‚Äôs pretty good, what do you think?

For some reason in my head the quote actually is ‚Äú100 times,‚Äù but I think that‚Äôs an exaggeration. I‚Äôm more comfortable with 10 times. So if nobody has made this quote, and I actually did make up this quote then that‚Äôs just fine with me. And if someone did say this, let me know so that I can give due credit.
